ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul Burow was a great help throughout the course.
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Burrow, Paul
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul Burow
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Burow, Paul

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul knows these topics well and brought a new perspective to the course through his settler colonialism lecture. He was approachable and helpful with homework assignments and with preparing for discussions.
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul was very helpful in articulating the concepts from class, and brainstorming for the final paper. I enjoyed his lecture on the last day very much.

Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul is clearly extremely knowledgeable and very smart. I felt comfortable with him and think he did a great job in the class. When we met with Paul in our groups I really appreciated the interactions with him. However, during the final course that Paul taught it felt too much like a lecture at a conference rather than suited for the class at hand. Maybe in part because it felt like a different style than Carol normally teaches but it felt a little too scripted and a little "too academic". I was able to grasp what Paul was communicating best during the Q & A or when he wasn't reading off his notes.

Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul was very helpful and responsive to requests for help--sometimes I did feel like he was sort of giving us the cheat sheet for how Carol likes to see things. Which was helpful, but also kind of odd.
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  Paul was excellent, he worked well with us and was always available to help especially when we were writing our term paper.
Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  He is very accessible and helpful.

Instructor: Paul Berne Burow  I thought the TA was an extremely valuable member of the class. His lecture at the end of the semester was quite good. He also made insightful comments during the weekly class discussions. If anything, I would have liked to hear more of his comments. I am not exactly sure why we had to meet with him before leading discussions. I found these meetings of limited use.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: There was incredibly too much reading in this course.
I think that every single FES student that plans to go into development or conservation fields should be required to take this course.

Professor Carpenter is excellent, and I think more FES students need this critical lens. However, sometimes lectures were difficult to get through. Perhaps if the material was presented more clearly (rather than jumping from one author to another and back), and also if she didn't just read dense notes, it might be more engaging. More of a summary of key ideas in conversation would be useful. I liked that our reading responses were thesis sentences.

Lectures could perhaps be somewhat shorter in length, and class discussion could be better moderated by student discussants. In other classes, student discussants would present a quick 10 minute response of key points and discussion would follow - this might be one way of encouraging deeper participation/discussion following the lectures.

I thought the course content was incredibly valuable, but its delivery was somewhat difficult. Sometimes the reading was very dense and difficult to get through (I would sometimes spend half of my weekend getting through assigned reading for this class). In addition, the lecture delivery was really tough to sit through. Carol has interesting content to provide, but she reads her lectures from typed notes, sometimes verbatim, and that makes for a really long initial hour and a half of class.

Question 14: I am impressed with this course because of my interest in International and rural development. It exposed me to interesting literature and shaped the way i think about development aid and conservation. I am very impressed with the interrelatedness and the connection between each week's reading and the previous and how it all addressed and exposed issue relating to development and conservation.

I think this is a critical course for any FESer. The ideas covered in the course are SO important. I think the professor got off on tangents too much. This was a bit distracting. Also, it was a bit hard to follow the professor when she reads off of her notes. A quick note about reading the class: when students aren't asking questions and nobody is commenting, this is generally an indicator that people are confused. The teacher would often ask the class if there were any questions and people would be quiet, for the most part. This is not a great sign. Even if people say they have no questions, they may be so confused that they don't know how to even being formulating a question.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: This course challenged our conventional thinking and assumptions regarding development and conservation interventions.
The readings were well-selected and reflected a broad spectrum of research questions in conservation and development.
Some of the discussions were really excellent, and I enjoyed a lot of the readings. Plenty of food for thought going forward.
Student led Class discussion session.
Readings
We could explore deeper scenarios via reading authors with broad conceptualizations and thinking.

This class opened my eyes to a whole new set of literature that I hadn't considered before, and really increase my literacy regarding issues in conservation and development. I've also gained a new language with which to speak about such issues that I find really helpful.

I think the practice of writing thesis statements is an extremely useful exercise. I think it would be helpful if the professor continued to post her own thesis statements throughout the semester. I'm not sure why she stops posting them so early in the semester. Having examples to work off of is never a bad thing. The readings for this course are also really great. At times, I felt I had to rush through the readings, but that is sometimes unavoidable. I felt the responsibility of leading class discussions was super valuable.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Needs to be more organized student discussion. More inclusivity.
none
Lectures

A more stimulating structure of student discussion would be useful - perhaps alternative formats could be tested? Alternately, it might be interesting if students gave the initial lecture and the lecturer acted as a respondent.

Some of the discussions really fell flat and I was a little baffled that about a third of the class could just sit there silently for all of it. There has to be a better way to engage people/incentivize discussion. It puts the entire burden on a few.
Individual guidance for what is expected in final papers and thesis sentences
I felt a little bit lost during lecture so may be focusing it on a more dynamic way would help.

The class periods are really long, and sometimes it felt overwhelming to do the readings, have a lecture on the readings, and then discuss the readings - there were times that I wished there were some new topics/case studies that were introduced in class that went beyond the readings.

I think the class discussions need to be more effectively managed. That is not to say that the professor needs to be more involved in the discussions. While it is nice to hear the professor's thoughts on a topic, the discussions should be a time for the students to talk about the readings. Sometimes I felt that the professor interjected too much. Another area of improvement for the course is the final term paper. I don't think there was enough guidance for the final term paper. I would also like if we were able to read some papers that were more like the papers we were asked to write in the end. So few classes do that. So few classes have the students read writing that is similar to the writing the students are asked to do. I would have liked to see examples from previous years of great papers.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I thought that the lectures and discussions flowed together very well.
Student led discussion session were interesting and this was a time we got express our ideas and view on the class readings.
N/A
The class lectures and discussions were effectively related.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course really helped to open my mind to the realities of the global development industrial complex and I will take these valuable insights into the field to attempt to understand, mitigate, re-focus, and improve destructive or misguided development and conservation interventions.
Excellent context for a broader course of study in environmental management/forestry. It makes you think a lot of the challenges of conservation policy and your responsibility in implementing it.
The course helps me understand the politics of aid in developing country context

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I thought it would help with my future career goals.
I took this course to gain a new perspective on conservation and development projects through the lens of power relations.
Interest in the content. There aren't a lot of other classes like this at FES.
Required component of my study.
Because i had taken Carol's class before and i liked it.
I'm really interested in conservation, and this course provided a lot of case studies on what has worked and what hasn't, and provided a language with which to speak about it.

I took the course because I wanted to take an anthropology course related to environmental management. I think anthropology is a critically important field for any FES student. I wish there was more anthropology courses offered at FES. Anthropology helps students see the world through different lenses.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes!
Yes
Definitely - surpassed my expectations.
Yes
Yes
Yes
Yes
I feel that I've taken more away from this course than I have from most other courses at Yale.

The knowledge I gained in this course is exactly the sort of knowledge I was looking for. At times, it was very focused on forestry. I would have liked if it was a little broader in scope. Some of my favorite readings were about TEK, wilderness, environmental management, economics, and participation. I felt these topics related well to all student interests. That being said, obviously the lessons learned from the more forestry-oriented articles can be abstracted and are applicable to all students. I think the practice of leading discussion is super valuable. Besides improving our reading and writing skills this was one of the more valuable skills gained through this class.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Everyone in the group pulled their weight and we worked well together to further develop our ideas and to discover new questions regarding the course information.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Make sure you have time for all the reading. There is a lot.
If you are thinking about going into fields having to do with development or conservation you should definitely take this course.
Be ready to think critically, and you'll be better for it
It would be useful to have some social science background before taking this course, although many people did fine without it.
Stay on top of readings--they're important. And participate in discussion. And don't be afraid to ask questions or challenge assumptions made.

This course is great if you want to understand the environment, development and society in developing world context. Initially the reading are hard, but ones you do it for the first two lecture, you get used to it. It also improves your writing and hones your ability to extract thesis or authors arguments from a text, a skill that is valuable regardless of academic background and interests
Read carefully the texts.
Definitely take it! Find time to meet with Carol early regarding the final paper. And definitely do all of the readings - it can be a lot but they're all helpful.

I would definitely recommend that students take the course. The readings for the course are great (for the most part). They are the best part of the course. The course will challenge your assumptions and helps students become more imaginative thinkers and more critical problem solvers. I don't think any student should go into environmental management without taking this course. It helps students become more ethical practitioners.
